commit_message:
Fix xio driver bug: cloned with src vol size

It's possible to create a volume from a source volume with
a larger size. However, xio driver does not extend
the volume when clone has finished. This patch fixes it.

The volume has not been created with OVO and a seperate patch
will be created to switch the dictionary to OVO implementation
regarding volume / snapshot to follow up Gorka's comments.

Co-Authored-By: Xinli Guan <xinli@us.ibm.com>

Change-Id: Icd626ff894e052f557f3da9439b217ed4924014e
Closes-Bug: #1554764

subject: Make infra specific beaker rspec template

Turns out the puppet openstack modules do run the legacy xenial beaker
rspec job. I had thought they were completely off of the legacy job
config but was wrong. This means we need new templates for infra that
add in the infra repos and need to restore the existing templates that
don't add in the infra repos for the puppet openstack modules.

Change-Id: Icf7ec289d51a3e7b7374f8aef5a94d18ec12bc94
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Make infra specific beaker rspec template

Turns out the puppet openstack modules do run the legacy xenial beaker
rspec job. I had thought they were completely off of the legacy job
config but was wrong. This means we need new templates for infra that
add in the infra repos and need to restore the existing templates that
don't add in the infra repos for the puppet openstack modules.

The error messages from libvirt are LANG aware.

OS, we may got non-ASCII from libvirt.

commit_message:
libvirt: do unicode conversion for error messages.

The error messages from libvirt are LANG aware.
If we deploy nova and libvirt on an non-English language
OS, we may got non-ASCII from libvirt.

We should use exception_to_unicode to cover this senario.

Change-Id: I485dc1c92aad8347b505d6ece9e6191da931ec72
Signed-off-by: Chen Hanxiao <chenhx@certusnet.com.cn>

", 'number': 2}]
commit_message:
Fix unstage after staging store denies write

If store_backend denies writing to store then glance_store will raise
'StorageWriteDenied' error. After catching this exception at glance
side, unstage call fails with TypeError as it requires 3 arguments
and only two were provided.

Passed 'staging_store' argument to _unstage call for correcting the
same.

Change-Id: I6d3d1b304e84fbfc1d653b3640ed92082f5b11cd
Closes-Bug: #1732835

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-09-27 01:07:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'placement - add nested resource providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class SRIOV_NET_VF
and we will need a way of indicating that the physical function
providing these virtual function resources is tagged with certain
attributes (could be vendor_id, product_id or something like physnet
tagging representing the physical network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable and this code includes an
online data migration to automatically populate the root_provider_uuid
field with the value of the resource_providers.uuid field for any
resource providers already in the DB.

We will be able to use both the root_provider_uuid and the
parent_provider_uuid in various queries from the resource tracker and
the scheduler to determine the compute hosts that have child providers
who can fulfill a particular requested amount of certain types of
resources like an SRIOV_NET_VF.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's root and
parent provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2016-09-27 02:34:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'placement - add nested resource providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class SRIOV_NET_VF
and we will need a way of indicating that the physical function
providing these virtual function resources is tagged with certain
attributes (could be vendor_id, product_id or something like physnet
tagging representing the physical network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

', 'number': 5}, {'created': '2016-10-12 17:23:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'placement: add nested resource providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class SRIOV_NET_VF
and we will need a way of indicating that the physical function
providing these virtual function resources is tagged with certain
attributes (could be vendor_id, product_id or something like physnet
tagging representing the physical network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable and this code includes an
online data migration to automatically populate the root_provider_uuid
field with the value of the resource_providers.uuid field for any
resource providers already in the DB.

We will be able to use both the root_provider_uuid and the
parent_provider_uuid in various queries from the resource tracker and
the scheduler to determine the compute hosts that have child providers
who can fulfill a particular requested amount of certain types of
resources like an SRIOV_NET_VF.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's root and
parent provider UUID actually points to an existing provider. Finally,
if an provider has its parent provider UUID set to a non-None value, we
automatically set that provider's root provider UUID to the root of the
parent provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the total
number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204

We will be able to use both the root_provider_uuid and the

the scheduler to determine the compute hosts that have child providers
who can fulfill a particular requested amount of certain types of
resources like an SRIOV_NET_VF.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's root and
parent provider UUID actually points to an existing provider. Finally,
if an provider has its parent provider UUID set to a non-None value, we
automatically set that provider's root provider UUID to the root of the
parent provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the total
number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204

', 'number': 17}, {'created': '2016-11-21 16:12:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'placement: add nested resource providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class SRIOV_NET_VF
and we will need a way of indicating that the physical function
providing these virtual function resources is tagged with certain
attributes (could be vendor_id, product_id or something like physnet
tagging representing the physical network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable and this code includes an
online data migration to automatically populate the root_provider_uuid
field with the value of the resource_providers.uuid field for any
resource providers already in the DB.

The root_provider_uuid field is intended to be an internal
implementation detail of the resource providers data model. Its value is
populated automatically when a provider is created. If the parent
provider UUID is set, then the root_provider_uuid is set to the
root_provider_uuid value of the parent. If parent is unset,
root_provider_uuid is set to the uuid attribute value of the provider
being created.

The root_provider_uuid field allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the total
number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable and this code includes an
online data migration to automatically populate the root_provider_uuid
field with the value of the resource_providers.uuid field for any
resource providers already in the DB.

The root_provider_uuid field is intended to be an internal
implementation detail of the resource providers data model. Its value is
populated automatically when a provider is created. If the parent
provider UUID is set, then the root_provider_uuid is set to the
root_provider_uuid value of the parent. If parent is unset,
root_provider_uuid is set to the value of the uuid attribute of the
provider being created.

The root_provider_uuid field allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the total
number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
Co-Authored-By: Moshe Levi <moshele@mellanox.com>

to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the total
number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
Co-Authored-By: Moshe Levi <moshele@mellanox.com>
', 'number': 31}, {'created': '2017-02-09 22:21:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'placement: add nested resource providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class SRIOV_NET_VF
and we will need a way of indicating that the physical function
providing these virtual function resources is tagged with certain
attributes (could be vendor_id, product_id or something like physnet
tagging representing the physical network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable and this code includes an
online data migration to automatically populate the root_provider_uuid
field with the value of the resource_providers.uuid field for any
resource providers already in the DB.

The root_provider_uuid field is intended to be an internal
implementation detail of the resource providers data model. Its value is
populated automatically when a provider is created. If the parent
provider UUID is set, then the root_provider_uuid is set to the
root_provider_uuid value of the parent. If parent is unset,
root_provider_uuid is set to the value of the uuid attribute of the
provider being created.

The root_provider_uuid field allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if

there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the total
number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable and this code includes an
online data migration to automatically populate the root_provider_uuid
field with the value of the resource_providers.uuid field for any
resource providers already in the DB.

The root_provider_uuid field is intended to be an internal
implementation detail of the resource providers data model. Its value
is populated automatically when a provider is created. If the parent
provider UUID is set, then the root_provider_uuid is set to the
root_provider_uuid value of the parent. If parent is unset,
root_provider_uuid is set to the value of the uuid attribute of the
provider being created.

The root_provider_uuid field allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the
total number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
Co-Authored-By: Moshe Levi <moshele@mellanox.com>

', 'number': 44}, {'created': '2017-10-10 17:09:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'placement: add nested resource providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class
SRIOV_NET_VF and we will need a way of indicating that the physical
function providing these virtual function resources is tagged with
certain traits (representing vendor_id, product_id or the physical
network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The database schema adds two new columns to the resource_providers
table that contain the internal integer IDs that correspond to the
user-facing UUID values:

 - root_provider_id
 - parent_provider_id

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable in the ResourceProvider
object definition, and this code includes an online data migration to
automatically populate the root_provider_id field with the value of the
resource_providers.id field for any resource providers already in the
DB.

The root_provider_id field value is populated automatically when a
provider is created. If the parent provider UUID is set, then the
root_provider_id is set to the root_provider_id value of the parent. If
parent is unset, root_provider_id is set to the value of the id
attribute of the provider being created. The corresponding UUID values
for root and parent provider are fetched in the queries that retrieves
resource provider data using two self-referential joins.

The root_provider_id column allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the
total number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The database schema adds two new columns to the resource_providers
table that contain the internal integer IDs that correspond to the
user-facing UUID values:

 - root_provider_id
 - parent_provider_id

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable in the ResourceProvider
object definition, and this code includes an online data migration to
automatically populate the root_provider_id field with the value of the
resource_providers.id field for any resource providers already in the
DB.

The root_provider_id field value is populated automatically when a
provider is created. If the parent provider UUID is set, then the
root_provider_id is set to the root_provider_id value of the parent. If
parent is unset, root_provider_id is set to the value of the id
attribute of the provider being created. The corresponding UUID values
for root and parent provider are fetched in the queries that retrieves
resource provider data using two self-referential joins.

The root_provider_id column allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the
total number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
Co-Authored-By: Moshe Levi <moshele@mellanox.com>

child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class
SRIOV_NET_VF and we will need a way of indicating that the physical
function providing these virtual function resources is tagged with
certain traits (representing vendor_id, product_id or the physical
network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The database schema adds two new columns to the resource_providers
table that contain the internal integer IDs that correspond to the
user-facing UUID values:

 - root_provider_id
 - parent_provider_id

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable in the ResourceProvider
object definition, and this code includes an online data migration to
automatically populate the root_provider_id field with the value of the
resource_providers.id field for any resource providers already in the
DB.

The root_provider_id field value is populated automatically when a
provider is created. If the parent provider UUID is set, then the
root_provider_id is set to the root_provider_id value of the parent. If
parent is unset, root_provider_id is set to the value of the id
attribute of the provider being created. The corresponding UUID values
for root and parent provider are fetched in the queries that retrieves
resource provider data using two self-referential joins.

The root_provider_id column allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the
total number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
Co-Authored-By: Moshe Levi <moshele@mellanox.com>

commit_message:
placement: add nested resource providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class
SRIOV_NET_VF and we will need a way of indicating that the physical
function providing these virtual function resources is tagged with
certain traits (representing vendor_id, product_id or the physical
network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The database schema adds two new columns to the resource_providers
table that contain the internal integer IDs that correspond to the
user-facing UUID values:

 - root_provider_id
 - parent_provider_id

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable in the ResourceProvider
object definition, and this code includes an online data migration to
automatically populate the root_provider_id field with the value of the
resource_providers.id field for any resource providers already in the
DB.

The root_provider_id field value is populated automatically when a
provider is created. If the parent provider UUID is set, then the
root_provider_id is set to the root_provider_id value of the parent. If
parent is unset, root_provider_id is set to the value of the id
attribute of the provider being created. The corresponding UUID values
for root and parent provider are fetched in the queries that retrieves
resource provider data using two self-referential joins.

The root_provider_id column allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the
total number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
Co-Authored-By: Moshe Levi <moshele@mellanox.com>

commit_message:
sort when using groupby

groupby requires items to be sorted as it's clumping consecutive
items together. also, just use itemgetter instead of lambda

Change-Id: I1676fc60ebc2c9ff03ea00cc67061fdfb3b50868

commit_message:
Remove the instack-undercloud-puppet-lint job

This job got migrated and its playbook deleted. The definition of the
job was left in the repo, so now we have errors on instack-undercloud
check jobs.

Removing the definition to fix the issue.

Depends-On: I87141dc9a8ecbb563c4bd63ea47b179e33166905
Change-Id: Iabf5c6d5e5c7677f9f5c0523daedbef3526f5f53
Closes-Bug: #1734348

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4694, 'name': 'Miguel Lavalle', 'email': 'miguel@mlavalle.com', 'username': 'minsel'}, {'_account_id': 6547, 'name': 'Andreas Jaeger', 'email': 'jaegerandi@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaegerandi'}, {'_account_id': 13252, 'name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott', 'display_name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott (frickler)', 'email': 'frickler@offenerstapel.de', 'username': 'jrosenboom'}, {'_account_id': 22318, 'name': 'Chandan Kumar', 'email': 'chandan.kumar@imaginea.com'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-28 19:45:19.000000000', 'files': ['zuul.d/projects.yaml'], 'message': "neutron: don't execute legacy in-tree tempest jobs for master

Those three legacy jobs - api plus two scenarios (both ovs/dvr and
linuxbridge) - rely on in-tree neutron tempest plugin that is going to
be removed with Ia21aad29d0bbf779583964db6f1665c9b3b83161. (The plugin
with all test cases was moved into a separate repo,
openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin.)

New jobs using the separate repo are already introduced for neutron
master branch, so at this point the legacy flavors are obsolete and
duplicate, and we should get rid of them to save resources as well as
move forward with tree cleanup.

There is ongoing work to move those jobs in-tree for stable branches:
I99ca4d4439782bd50a11f9d0f5ae6b0cfc4081c2. While we wait on the work to
finish, it makes sense to unblock work on tempest plugin by limiting the
legacy jobs to stable branches only.

Change-Id: Ie9516b203ca2efee41931972357900afd54ec71a
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
neutron: don't execute legacy in-tree tempest jobs for master

Those three legacy jobs - api plus two scenarios (both ovs/dvr and
linuxbridge) - rely on in-tree neutron tempest plugin that is going to
be removed with Ia21aad29d0bbf779583964db6f1665c9b3b83161. (The plugin
with all test cases was moved into a separate repo,
openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin.)

New jobs using the separate repo are already introduced for neutron
master branch, so at this point the legacy flavors are obsolete and
duplicate, and we should get rid of them to save resources as well as
move forward with tree cleanup.

There is ongoing work to move those jobs in-tree for stable branches:
I99ca4d4439782bd50a11f9d0f5ae6b0cfc4081c2. While we wait on the work to
finish, it makes sense to unblock work on tempest plugin by limiting the
legacy jobs to stable branches only.

Change-Id: Ie9516b203ca2efee41931972357900afd54ec71a

Depends-On: Ia070c067f4f27bbf0a29f981777aa8de8c878a15

subject: Add required projects to legacy puppet rspec jobs
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-29 18:50:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Add required projects to legacy puppet rspec jobs

These rspec jobs install the entire set of modules declared by
system-config's modules env file. It also does so from source using
zuul-cloner so that we can do cross repo testing of our puppet modules.
Unfortunately these required projects were not listed on the jobs
resulting in errors from the zuul cloner shim when attempting to clone
these repos.

Add in all our puppet modules as required projects (as listed by the
zuul cloner shim) so that we fix this problem.

Change-Id: Iff50f517bb92fd19a620ab5b433cd2e52702cec0
", 'number': 1}, {'created': '2017-11-29 19:10:33.000000000', 'files': ['zuul.d/zuul-legacy-jobs.yaml', 'zuul.d/zuul-legacy-project-templates.yaml'], 'message': "Add required projects to legacy puppet rspec jobs

These rspec jobs install the entire set of modules declared by
system-config's modules env file. It also does so from source using
zuul-cloner so that we can do cross repo testing of our puppet modules.
Unfortunately these required projects were not listed on the jobs
resulting in errors from the zuul cloner shim when attempting to clone
these repos.

Add in all our puppet modules as required projects (as listed by the
zuul cloner shim) so that we fix this problem. We do this via a new job
that is infra specific so that we don't have to modify the required
projects list in multiple places to get the correct list.

Change-Id: Iff50f517bb92fd19a620ab5b433cd2e52702cec0
", 'number': 2}]
commit_message:
Add required projects to legacy puppet rspec jobs

These rspec jobs install the entire set of modules declared by
system-config's modules env file. It also does so from source using
zuul-cloner so that we can do cross repo testing of our puppet modules.
Unfortunately these required projects were not listed on the jobs
resulting in errors from the zuul cloner shim when attempting to clone
these repos.

Add in all our puppet modules as required projects (as listed by the
zuul cloner shim) so that we fix this problem. We do this via a new job
that is infra specific so that we don't have to modify the required
projects list in multiple places to get the correct list.

Change-Id: Iff50f517bb92fd19a620ab5b433cd2e52702cec0

subject: Set agent debug config defaults to service default
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-18 14:36:50.000000000', 'files': ['releasenotes/notes/agent-debug-option-defaults-to-service-default-8466c8808919b7b2.yaml', 'manifests/agents/l3.pp', 'spec/classes/neutron_agents_l3_spec.rb', 'spec/classes/neutron_agents_l2gw_spec.rb', 'spec/classes/neutron_agents_metadata_spec.rb', 'manifests/agents/l2gw.pp', 'manifests/agents/metering.pp', 'spec/classes/neutron_agents_metering_spec.rb', 'manifests/agents/metadata.pp'], 'message': "Set agent debug config defaults to service default

A few of the neutron agents had a default of 'false' for the debug
flag. This interferes with the common practice of enabling debug through
a common configuration file (e.g. /etc/neutron.conf). This patch changes
the default to ::os_service_default allowing it to either use the
service default, values set in some common configuration or explicitly.

Change-Id: I7d7a1e4776861dc8d94a143edc0df76c3f963ef8
Closes-Bug: #1733071
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Set agent debug config defaults to service default

A few of the neutron agents had a default of 'false' for the debug
flag. This interferes with the common practice of enabling debug through
a common configuration file (e.g. /etc/neutron.conf). This patch changes
the default to ::os_service_default allowing it to either use the
service default, values set in some common configuration or explicitly.

Change-Id: I7d7a1e4776861dc8d94a143edc0df76c3f963ef8
Closes-Bug: #1733071

commit_message:
tripleo-ui: run javascript-tarball

Everytime we touch npm-shrinkwrap.json and package.json, we would like
to make sure that a tarball can be generated with npm tool.
For that, let's use build-javascript-tarball that exists in zuul-jobs
project.

Note: tripleo-ui seems to be the first project using this job.

Depends-On: Ida7130b482de0328a5517b8fe827efaff25b9461
Change-Id: I214b78eca3b2282e4c7f02974beac6dfb162043c

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 5756, 'name': 'Terry Wilson', 'email': 'twilson@redhat.com', 'username': 'otherwiseguy'}, {'_account_id': 8655, 'name': 'Jakub Libosvar', 'email': 'libosvar@redhat.com', 'username': 'jlibosva'}, {'_account_id': 8788, 'name': 'Miguel Angel Ajo', 'email': 'mangelajo@redhat.com', 'username': 'mangelajo'}, {'_account_id': 9656, 'name': 'Ihar Hrachyshka', 'email': 'ihrachys@redhat.com', 'username': 'ihrachys'}, {'_account_id': 20229, 'name': 'Omer Anson', 'email': 'omer.anson@toganetworks.com', 'username': 'oanson'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23804, 'name': 'Daniel Alvarez', 'email': 'dalvarez@redhat.com', 'username': 'dalvarez'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-29 05:33:40.000000000', 'files': ['ovsdbapp/tests/functional/schema/open_vswitch/test_impl_idl.py', 'ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/connection.py', 'ovsdbapp/exceptions.py'], 'message': "Don't throw NotConnectedError in queue_txn

Before Ifc74a834ca1a7d914c7ca66d71b47694f9eef1e5, queueing a
transaction before we had connected to an ovsdb-server would
happily work. When the connection started, the run() method would
pull the queued transaction off the queue and process it. Adding
the exception added a race condition in existing code, so this
patch removes it.

Change-Id: I0b620b0040ef5f7cb99d2f27140f605e97f95512
Related-Bug: #1731063
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Don't throw NotConnectedError in queue_txn

Before Ifc74a834ca1a7d914c7ca66d71b47694f9eef1e5, queueing a
transaction before we had connected to an ovsdb-server would
happily work. When the connection started, the run() method would
pull the queued transaction off the queue and process it. Adding
the exception added a race condition in existing code, so this
patch removes it.

Change-Id: I0b620b0040ef5f7cb99d2f27140f605e97f95512
Related-Bug: #1731063

commit_message:
Implement availability_zone_hints for networks and routers.

Adds an optional parameter to the create_network and
create_router-methods, for use with availability zone-scheduling of
network agents.

commit_message:
Repropose application credentials to queens

This proposal for the Queens release updates the spec to cover the
changes discussed at the Denver PTG[1]. It also fixes some
inconsistencies that were introduced in the final stages of the approval
process the last time, and also makes some minor wording corrections.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-September/122087.html

Change-Id: I7024208cc567f761a333001bf872af46fa0cf323

commit_message:
Add errors file to be indexed by logstash

In tripleo we grep for errors in logs and put them in one file.
This patch is for indexing only errors file in logstash server.

Change-Id: I95021ca826c75d7750bc2e56243ecc638bc1a502

[{'created': '2017-11-27 17:46:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Improve configure-unbound role to support configuring TTLs

Given the volume and ephemeral nature of the nodes we are running jobs
on, we're interested in raising the minimum TTL to ensure we're not
needlessly querying domains all the time.

Some domains such as github.com or fedoraproject.org have low TTLs and
we suspect there is a correlation between their low TTLs and the fact
that we're seeing increased DNS lookup rates for these domains.

- Prefix variables with "unbound_" to avoid potential clashes between
  roles
- Add support for configuring cache-min-ttl and cache-max-ttl
- Improve integration tests

commit_message:
Add support for configuring TTLs in configure-unbound

Given the volume and ephemeral nature of the nodes we are running jobs
on, we're interested in raising the minimum TTL to ensure we're not
needlessly querying domains all the time.

Some domains such as github.com or fedoraproject.org have low TTLs and
we suspect there is a correlation between their low TTLs and the fact
that we're seeing increased DNS lookup rates for these domains.

Change-Id: I6d9656cb07a694fc2f54f256a63af814c034ffb8

- Improve README
- Improve integration test coverage
- Prefix variable names with "unbound_" to avoid clashes between
  different roles
- Unbound will very likely be installed but don't assume it is.
  If it is installed, we don't need to ensure /etc/unbound exists,
  it will exist.

commit_message:
General improvements to configure-unbound role

- Improve README
- Improve integration test coverage
- Prefix variable names with "unbound_" to avoid clashes between
  different roles
- Unbound will very likely be installed but don't assume it is.
  Add an assertion to fail early if it isn't.

Change-Id: Ib8ca105938afdc0ccb1f524df3cae916c845efb8

[{'created': '2017-11-28 22:38:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Port wiki bugs pages (1 of ?)

This is the first in a series of patches to port pages related to Bugs
from the OpenStack wiki to project-team-guide.

This patch ports https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Bugs

The original content is preserved, warts and all.  (There are some known
errata; they will be fixed in subsequent patches.)  Existing links to
other wiki pages are preserved for now - they'll need to be updated in
subsequent patches that port the referenced pages.

Change-Id: I870aae068d4166c9818a85bcdb77f16e12c28bba
", 'number': 1}, {'created': '2017-11-29 14:46:10.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/index.rst', 'doc/source/bugs.rst'], 'message': "Port wiki bugs pages (1 of ?)

This is the first in a series of patches to port pages related to Bugs
from the OpenStack wiki to project-team-guide.

This patch ports https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Bugs

In the process of porting the data, the following changes were made:

- Our use of Launchpad states is updated ('Fix Released' is set when a
  fix is merged; 'Fix Committed' is not used).
- Project-specific links to bug reporting landing pages are removed as
  being hard to keep current, and out of scope for the project team
  guide.
- The Bug list maintainers section is removed, likewise.

Change-Id: I870aae068d4166c9818a85bcdb77f16e12c28bba
", 'number': 2}]
commit_message:
Port wiki bugs pages (1 of ?)

This is the first in a series of patches to port pages related to Bugs
from the OpenStack wiki to project-team-guide.

This patch ports https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Bugs

In the process of porting the data, the following changes were made:

- Our use of Launchpad states is updated ('Fix Released' is set when a
  fix is merged; 'Fix Committed' is not used).
- Project-specific links to bug reporting landing pages are removed as
  being hard to keep current, and out of scope for the project team
  guide.
- The Bug list maintainers section is removed, likewise.

Change-Id: I870aae068d4166c9818a85bcdb77f16e12c28bba

subject: Multi-region support in shared Keystone service deployment
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-08-16 02:35:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'User region name from AVAILABLE_REGIONS if provided

Currently, even if AVAILABLE_REGIONS is configed, openstack_auth will
still get the the first matched region from service catalog which may
be different with the provided one.

This patch gives operators the capability that config all regions in
AVAILABLE_REGIONS for a shared Keystone service, and let the end user
select which region she will log in, rather than switching region each
time after login.

A following patch will propose to Horizon repo to not show region
selector if all the auth_url in AVAILABLE_REGIONS are the same.

commit_message:
Multi-region support in shared Keystone service deployment

Currently, Horizon does not support login with specified region in
shared-keystone, multi-region deployment, the existing
AVAILABLE_REGIONS only works with multi-keystone, multi-region
environment. This patch provides end user the ability to select
region when log in Horizon. A new setting called
'OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_REGION_CHOICES' is introduced in Horizon config
file (in a following patch). The 'AVAILABLE_REGIONS' setting takes
precedence over 'OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_REGION_CHOICES'.

Implements: blueprint horizon-multi-region-support
Change-Id: I7e7ffdc8a56dad9aa114497f982b035e521060aa

commit_message:
Fix the loading of modules with undefined pattern

We introduced the ability to use an undefined pattern in the
"Load kernel module task", but we also test the absence of
patterns in a previous task.

That task doesn't handle an undefined pattern.
This patch allows the user to load a module which is not shipped
with the distro, therefore not included in the
``/boot/config-<kernel_version> file``.

With this patch, we allow the loading of a module only by name,
without a pattern.

Change-Id: Iaed1afe728a239c5794e4fbe815f798ccd6a8d82
Signed-off-by: Dimitrios Markou <mardim@intracom-telecom.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe@evrard.me>

commit_message:
Add New in Pike note to using db_sync check

This change adds a note (*New in Pike*) to the section for running
db_sync --check to clarify which release this feature was added. This
is similar to other sections in this document that specify the release
that a feature was added in and when it is available.

Change-Id: I7d778fa249997bb24e4563d6960910b93637bbf2
Closes-Bug: #1734549

The commit fixes an issue in renewing connections to Swift in case
if a given token is about to expire soon. get_auth_ref() returned
 a new auth_ref each time it was called so the will_expire_soon()
 call was useless since it always returned False. Now the cached

', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Use cached auth_ref instead of gettin a new one each time

The commit fixes an issue in renewing connections to Swift in case
if a given token is about to expire soon. get_auth_ref() returned
 a new auth_ref each time it was called so the will_expire_soon()
 call was useless since it always returned False. Now the cached
auth_ref property is used instead.
Closes-Bug:#1733502

Change-Id: I6cb53aec6798f965cf2a120d4f676a43bca5046a

commit_message:
Fix tests that were changing settings but not reverting

There were two tests that modified settings but did not revert them
to their original setting after. This patch makes them use the config
fixture so they will be cleaned up after the test ends.

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-08-29 23:00:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Save updated libvirt domain XML after swapping volume

When a user calls the volume-update API, we swap_volume in the libvirt
driver from the old volume attachment to the new volume attachment.
Currently, we're saving the domain XML with the old configuration prior
to updating the volume and upon a soft-reboot request, it results in an
error:

  Instance soft reboot failed: Cannot access storage file <old path>

and falls back to a hard reboot, which is like pulling the power cord,
possibly resulting in file system inconsistencies.

This changes to saving the new, updated domain XML after the volume
swap.

Closes-Bug: #1713857

Change-Id: I166cde5ad8b00699e4ec02609f0d7b69236d855d

commit_message:
Save updated libvirt domain XML after swapping volume

When a user calls the volume-update API, we swap_volume in the libvirt
driver from the old volume attachment to the new volume attachment.
Currently, we're saving the domain XML with the old configuration prior
to updating the volume and upon a soft-reboot request, it results in an
error:

  Instance soft reboot failed: Cannot access storage file <old path>

and falls back to a hard reboot, which is like pulling the power cord,
possibly resulting in file system inconsistencies.

This changes to saving the new, updated domain XML after the volume
swap.

Closes-Bug: #1713857

Change-Id: I166cde5ad8b00699e4ec02609f0d7b69236d855d

commit_message:
Fix Kibana plugin config duplication

This commit fixes the problem of the Kibana plugin's instances
list getting appended to every time monasca-setup runs. See
the referenced story for details. It also adds a cautionary

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-16 15:21:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "scripts: scripts-library.sh: Use pgrep -f to find the dstat process

The dstat process is actually a python script so running 'pgrep dstat'
will not match it

~# pgrep dstat
~# ps aux|grep dstat
root      5322  1.0  0.2  42888  8876 pts/0    S    16:16   0:00 python /usr/bin/dstat -tcmsdn --top-cpu --top-mem --top-bio --nocolor --output dstat.csv 3

However, we can use 'pgrep -f' to search for 'dstat' in the entire
procees string.

~# pgrep -f dstat
5322

commit_message:
scripts: scripts-library.sh: Use pgrep -f to find the dstat process

The dstat process is actually a python script so running 'pgrep dstat'
will not match it

~# pgrep dstat
~# ps aux|grep dstat
root      5322  1.0  0.2  42888  8876 pts/0    S    16:16   0:00 python /usr/bin/dstat -tcmsdn --top-cpu --top-mem --top-bio --nocolor --output dstat.csv 3

However, we can use 'pgrep -f' to search for 'dstat' in the entire
procees string.

~# pgrep -f dstat
5322

Change-Id: I17c181bf957626cc11a1fe6f954e54c8abbfbd93

commit_message:
Make test_periodic_task.test_back_to_back_job more consistent

The test `test_back_to_back_job` was relying on a delay to get a
condition to happen. This created situations where the test did not pass
as a result of race conditions. This patch changes this to a set of
events that trigger the continuation of the test.

Change-Id: I98a3c9a3cdd6f12d6bcf2394b8dea455e0307b31

commit_message:
Pass bindep profiles matching tox environments

So that people can put things like:

  pypy [pypy]

or

  python3-dev-all [platform:dpkg py35]

into their bindep files, add bindep_profile variables to the tox jobs.

Change-Id: I7c22e23b73ddfc18ee28e87d34d1988417b49ccb

commit_message:
Add support for configured NAT source variable

In some clouds there are more than one potential NAT source and shade's
auto_ip can't figure it out propery. os-client-config added a config
option similar to nat_destination called nat_source to help people set a
config in such environments. Add support for it.

Change-Id: I4b50c2323a487b5ce90f9d38a48be249cfb739c5
Depends-On: I3d8dd6d734a1013d2d4a43e11c3538c3a345820b

commit_message:
Handle race condition deleting security group rule

It is possible that during the `_update_security_group_rules` operation,
the security group rule which is to be deleted gets removed by some
other external operation.   If this happens, it raises a NotFound
exception is not handled which can lead to a load balancer stuck in
a PENDING_DELETE status.

Depends-On: I97b52b80efb33749647229a55147a08afa112dd2
Change-Id: Ic9ebe8392758f3de5fc6a94f815f83d6de113188
Story: 2001300
Task: 5851

commit_message:
Run dstat in gate tests

This will enable dstat dumps at 3 second intervals in the background
during gate jobs. In the gate job exit tasks, dstat_graph[1] will be
used to generate an HTML compilation of the dstat data.

[1] https://github.com/Dabz/dstat_graph

Change-Id: I8475098a75528f8260a41f853a243b08296e3855
(cherry picked from commit af28cf025ba0ccbad8bca215de767fb97d0cc1c3)

commit_message:
Zuul: add file extension to playbook path

Zuul now supports including the file extension on the playbook path
and omitting the extension is now deprecrated.  Update references
to include the extension.

Change-Id: I96d9772d363305fd65119d1195cc25a508ec33dc

commit_message:
Port wiki bugs pages (2 of ?)

This is the second in a series of patches to port pages related to Bugs
from the OpenStack wiki to project-team-guide.

This patch ports https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Bug_Tags

The original content is preserved, warts and all.  (There are some known
errata; they will be fixed in subsequent patches.)  Existing links to
other wiki pages are preserved for now - they may need to be updated if
subsequent patches port the referenced pages.

Change-Id: Iac3cc2d9c0a0755c0545cc0573ab9e7c24493866

commit_message:
Fix Ansible 2.3 bump breaking virt task

As of Ansible 2.3, autostart is now an idempotent VM attribute instead
and should be called accordingly.

Depends-On: I62f8c1556c94c132215b760d9597488659762e6f
Change-Id: I96e4da099845ea8cb821e6ffb12053800a56ce9c

commit_message:
Enable designate to list on all interfaces

This is a fix to enable designate to listen on all interfaces when the
charm designate is installed on a unit with multiple interfaces.

Change-Id: I96f23532d18550d0e27153d60f1003016958985b
Closes-Bug: #1734156

commit_message:
bagpipe-bgp: IPVPN OVS driver, advanced options

Mark as advanced some options of OVS driver for IPVPN

Needs an oslo-config version > 4.12, one that will
include Iec6997ee26f618ba6d5250f0597c83b4a3df02cd .

Change-Id: Iddff5108ab64d7045c51daea0dd316c0d44ecb97

commit_message:
Add log when receiving SIGHUP signal

As the daemon will reload its configuration files and reopen its
logfiles instead of exiting when receiving SIGHUP signal. So we
need some necessary logs about this event.

Change-Id: I8e5f11058bd26542a52f2fc0063ccdafccf53946

[{'created': '2017-05-22 17:34:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': '[WIP] Use local facts for MariaDB status

and a module, use local facts to check the MariaDB
status.

Change-Id: If189a8192f22aafb168587361ca8e6903c918697
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2017-09-27 18:52:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': '[WIP] Revise role using dynamic facts

Instead of using a series of set facts, CLI outputs
and a module, use local facts to check the MariaDB
status.

The desired outcome is to radically simplify the
role, while retaining the same functionality.

TODO:
- get it working for Ubuntu
- get it working for CentOS/SuSE
- write up release notes

Change-Id: If189a8192f22aafb168587361ca8e6903c918697
', 'number': 2}, {'created': '2017-11-16 22:38:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Tune-up the galera role for efficiency

The galera server role has quite a bit going on within it and because of
recent improvements in Ansible we can make better use of tasks, blocks,
facts, local facts, and organization. This change tunes the role up
following some of our better/more modern patterns allowing the role to
not only be more efficient but also easier to understand.

commit_message:
Tune-up the galera role for efficiency

The galera server role has quite a bit going on within it and because of
recent improvements in Ansible we can make better use of tasks, blocks,
facts, local facts, and organization. This change tunes the role up
following some of our better/more modern patterns allowing the role to
not only be more efficient but also easier to understand and improves
the roles idempotency.

Change-Id: If189a8192f22aafb168587361ca8e6903c918697
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Use gnocchi-api binary for wsgi script

WSGI script gnocchi/rest/app.wsgi has been removed in [1] which has
been included in release 4.1.0 and gnocchi-api must be used instead [2].

Note that new version has been bumped in RDO but not ubuntu yet, so
this patch is switching the wsgi script only for Red Hat deployments.

[1] https://github.com/gnocchixyz/gnocchi/commit/cef3396908947b6a8437476c899e6d5cec48a6d5#diff-f6608875dec4d7646c38d649181fd350
[2] https://github.com/gnocchixyz/gnocchi/blob/176c1332f6279dfa3a8238c9e017769553e59f02/releasenotes/notes/wsgi-script-deprecation-c6753a844ca0b411.yaml

Change-Id: Ibf901844e8319eec9c60f7c5c27770c89aae6427
Closes-Bug: #1735118

commit_message:
Stop passing auth_token to ironic-inspector-client

This has been deprecated long ago, and will be removed really soon.
Create a Token authentication, build a Session and pass it instead.
This reflects how a session was created with auth_token inside the
client previously.

Change-Id: I3ce2916872b6ba4c36d4d6f294456454eee78314

subject: Fix container restart handler
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-29 10:02:01.000000000', 'files': ['tests/test-containers-functional.yml', 'handlers/main.yml'], 'message': 'Fix container restart handler

The handler would try and stop a container before restarting it however
if the container was already stopped the handler would fail instead of
simply moving on to the next task. This change makes the "stop" portion
of the task detect the return status code of "2" when restarting the
container. If the return code is "2" we know that the container is
already stopped and that no change has occurred.

For the sake of consistency and to ensure the greatest chance for
success the test task that stops a container has also been given the
same setup.

Change-Id: Ia4856f36b2d106d987e3c774f31493e25a23d4b5
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit ff3441c90abbcb76a0f1b2fdf6d60b4ea0854cb2)
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Fix container restart handler

The handler would try and stop a container before restarting it however
if the container was already stopped the handler would fail instead of
simply moving on to the next task. This change makes the "stop" portion
of the task detect the return status code of "2" when restarting the
container. If the return code is "2" we know that the container is
already stopped and that no change has occurred.

For the sake of consistency and to ensure the greatest chance for
success the test task that stops a container has also been given the
same setup.

Change-Id: Ia4856f36b2d106d987e3c774f31493e25a23d4b5
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit ff3441c90abbcb76a0f1b2fdf6d60b4ea0854cb2)

commit_message:
Add explain of mapping group attribute

As we use federation protocol, assign authorization to ephemeral
users by mapping to groups. Setting this mapping does not add the
ephemeral user to the group and the user is not a member of the group.
Only authorization for the user is same as role assignments to the
group on a project or domain.

This patch add explain about the group mapping

Change-Id: I9faa7d57037af3c2cf6ccfda8d853693fa5eb628

add 'UNKNOWN' status in compute CDM, for compute nodes disabled
not by watcher, so no audit will react on them.
When a node is "disabled", we can use "disabled_reason"(prefix `watcher_`)
to specify the compute nodes disabled by watcher. When building compute CDM,
if the disabled nodes with 'disabled_reason' 'watcher_disabled', we set them
in 'disabled' status, otherwise set them in 'unknown' status.

commit_message:
extend-node-status

add 'disabled_reason' filed into 'ComputeNode' resource, to distinguish
which nodes are disabled by Watcher and which are not by Watcher.

Implements:blueprint extend-node-status

Change-Id: I7175f14870834a4582e45309529d7e8d9fbb2e6f

commit_message:
Dockerhub publisher job

This patchset contains two patches.

1. This patchset includes pushing mechanism for daily periodic jobs.
   (cherry picked from commit c506e626e7443fb95180807013082fb281390376)

2. Fixup small bug with dockerhub publisher
   Jinja2 vs gotpl...
   (cherry picked from commit 9674e2da1c1e0c5efffdace8e12849912210e197)
Change-Id: I27a54eb9202ac5f3e9b3ef9c307e81475e8833f5

subject: Reduce timer for periodic task tests
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-23 17:45:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Reduce timer for periodic task tests

With the timer set to 0.1 the execution of the tests depending on that
timer take almost double the time and unnecesarly. There have been cases
of the tests hitting the their wait timeouts when the system is under
load in the CI. By lowering it to 0 we achieve the same testing but
without the delays, hopefully this will reduce the amount of random
failures.

Change-Id: I61bd4a4309e274546fea2616002c4e0cc8a9e37d
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2017-11-29 07:28:50.000000000', 'files': ['networking_odl/tests/unit/journal/test_periodic_task.py'], 'message': 'Reduce timer for periodic task tests

With the timer set to 0.1 the execution of the tests depending on that
timer take almost double the time and unnecesarly. There have been cases
of the tests hitting the their wait timeouts when the system is under
load in the CI. By lowering it to 0 we achieve the same testing but
without the delays, hopefully this will reduce the amount of random

Change-Id: I61bd4a4309e274546fea2616002c4e0cc8a9e37d
', 'number': 2}]
commit_message:
Reduce timer for periodic task tests

With the timer set to 0.1 the execution of the tests depending on that
timer take almost double the time and unnecesarly. There have been cases
of the tests hitting the their wait timeouts when the system is under
load in the CI. By lowering it to 0 we achieve the same testing but
without the delays, hopefully this will reduce the amount of random
failures.

Change-Id: I61bd4a4309e274546fea2616002c4e0cc8a9e37d

commit_message:
Add id for API responses

The API response of many barbican action contains only full url.
This url also contains endpoint information that is stored in keystone.
Other API calls like secret delete need just the UUID which is the best
value to identify the entry.

APIImpact

Change-Id: If95242294b01a221708f745b9e6a834d5887619f

According to the comment, this test was skipped because it expected
the dhcp interface to be present which is not true. The reason why this
test has to be skipped is because the connection is checked through a
ping command from the spoofed port and replies won't reach the
destination because of the OVN ARP responder: ICMP replies will be sent
to the original MAC address and not to the spoofed one.

Let's continue to skip it until [0] gets fixed.

commit_message:
Tempest test_port_security_macspoofing_port was skipped for wrong reason

According to the comment, this test was skipped because it expected
the dhcp interface to be present which is not true. The reason why this
test has to be skipped is because the connection is checked through a
ping command from the spoofed port and replies won't reach the
destination because of the OVN ARP responder: ICMP replies will be sent
to the original MAC address and not to the spoofed one.

Let's continue to skip it until [0] gets fixed.

[0] https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1728886

Change-Id: I3a8d2c04f34eab241350e88f3e0b6f57d3dd37ca

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-29 10:59:10.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/yaml2ical/post.yaml'], 'message': 'Fix publication of IRC meetings ICS files

During transition to Zuulv3, an error was introduced in the ICS
files publication post-job, resulting in the "calendars" directory
itself to be copied to $path/calendars, instead of the ICS files
present in the directory. ICS files were were therefore being
published to $path/calendars/calendars. This commit restores
publication to $path/calendars.

Change-Id: Ifebd883826341b4d4f21f2f114b0a87582845ab3
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Fix publication of IRC meetings ICS files

During transition to Zuulv3, an error was introduced in the ICS
files publication post-job, resulting in the "calendars" directory
itself to be copied to $path/calendars, instead of the ICS files
present in the directory. ICS files were were therefore being
published to $path/calendars/calendars. This commit restores
publication to $path/calendars.

Change-Id: Ifebd883826341b4d4f21f2f114b0a87582845ab3

commit_message:
Preserve comments in INI files

config_template currently strips comments out from the INI files. This
commit adds support for comments.

The default ConfigParser supports reading comments but it doesn't writes
them back. There are other libraries that have better support for
comments, however, adopting another library would require a bigger
refactor of this code.

Change-Id: I376be69cd2cf34dc147f9ade716791125a424e2c

subject: Remove hard-coded policy choices for creating a server group
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-19 23:45:36.000000000', 'files': ['openstackclient/compute/v2/server_group.py', 'openstackclient/tests/unit/compute/v2/test_server_group.py'], 'message': 'Remove hard-coded policy choices for creating a server group

The hard-coded choices for the server group policy make it impossible
to create a server group with the soft-affinity or
soft-anti-affinity policy rules which were added in compute API
microversion 2.15. This removes the hard-coded choices so that the
policy is restricted on the server side rather than the client side.

Change-Id: Ib3dc39422ac1015872d56ae2fdeddf0f29613494
Closes-Bug: #1732938
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Remove hard-coded policy choices for creating a server group

The hard-coded choices for the server group policy make it impossible
to create a server group with the soft-affinity or
soft-anti-affinity policy rules which were added in compute API
microversion 2.15. This removes the hard-coded choices so that the
policy is restricted on the server side rather than the client side.

Change-Id: Ib3dc39422ac1015872d56ae2fdeddf0f29613494
Closes-Bug: #1732938

Commit 53a6cce9ed08 ("Use handlers to restart services and move dnsmasq
to a unit file") removed the ifup-post script on CentOS but we are still

to a unit file") removed the ifup-post script on CentOS but we are still

commit_message:
tasks: lxc_net: Do not source non-existing network script on CentOS

Commit 53a6cce9ed08 ("Use handlers to restart services and move dnsmasq
to a unit file") removed the ifup-post script on CentOS but we are still
sourcing it in the main network script and it's causing problems when
trying to bring the lxcbr0 interface up.

[root@localhost network-scripts]# ifup lxcbr0
RTNETLINK answers: File exists
/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifup-post: line 115: /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifup-post-lxcbr0: No such file or directory

Backport note:
The above-mentioned commit was included in
https://review.openstack.org/517341

Change-Id: Icf788fd82e298b7e17e784e0d27898f93e7441aa
(cherry picked from commit 925e42afe7dd8457d74ddd2f969f81704393659f)

commit_message:
Ensure net=host pods can use k8s DNS

This change switches the dnsPolicy on net=host pods to ensure they can
access the k8s DNS service. This patch removes the need for the
resolv.conf hack. ClusterFirstWithHostNet is available from kubernetes
version 1.6+.

Change-Id: I4982cd0a44059f84cd609bd9aa2bf69faa6921f6

commit_message:
Add ability to set keepalived virtual_router_id in clouds.yaml

In order to run multiple kolla-k8s deployments in the same environment
when both are running keepalived we need to be able to override the
keepalived virtual_router_id to prevent them conflicting with each
other.

Change-Id: I04b755e6b2631438596886527230cd349571a7ad

commit_message:
Add ironic provision network IP addresses to API external IPs

For the ironic baremetal servers to call back to the Ironic API they
need to know where to talk to, to make this HA we should ensure that
each conductor exposes the ironic API on its provisoning network IP
address. To do that this patch allows to specify a list of the conductor
provision network IPs in clouds.yaml so we can add them to the
ironic-api-svc external IPs list.

Change-Id: I4566f6eccf4d74240f0e96e420b285baa2bf06ee

commit_message:
Ensure ironic-inspector declares with ports it binds too

Ensure that we declare which ports inspector binds to, so that the k8s
system can make decisions based on it, also ensure that ironic-inspector
binds to a different port than is specified in the kubernetes service to
prevent conflicts between ironic-inspector and kube-proxy exposing the
services external IP address.

Change-Id: I1fafd15486bda5a41e3c0e28f2acaf14f7642801

subject: Implement a proper WSREP check for galera
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-16 17:47:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Implement a proper WSREP check for galera

The galera cluster rely on WSREP for cluster consistency. While the
default MySQL monitor will allow us to know when the database node is
minimally functional it does not provide the ability to query the node
state allowing loadbalancers, operators, and deployers to know a node
is healthy prior to being allowed to accept connections. This change
implements the checkcluster script as provided by the fine folks at
Percona. The implementation of this check follows the guild-lines noted
here [0]. With this in-place, we'll be able to convert our haproxy check
for the galera cluster nodes to use an HTTP check on port 9200 instead
of the default MySQL login which will provide for a more robust and
fault tolerant cluster.

[0] https://www.percona.com/doc/percona-xtradb-cluster/LATEST/howtos/virt_sandbox.html
Closes-Bug: #1665667

Change-Id: Ie1b3b9724dd33de1d90634166e585ecceb1f4c96
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
", 'number': 1}, {'created': '2017-11-16 22:53:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Implement a proper WSREP check for galera

The galera cluster rely on WSREP for cluster consistency. While the
default MySQL monitor will allow us to know when the database node is
minimally functional it does not provide the ability to query the node
state allowing loadbalancers, operators, and deployers to know a node
is healthy prior to being allowed to accept connections. This change

Percona. The implementation of this check follows the guild-lines noted
here [0]. With this in-place, we'll be able to convert our haproxy check
for the galera cluster nodes to use an HTTP check on port 9200 instead
of the default MySQL login which will provide for a more robust and
fault tolerant cluster.

[0] https://www.percona.com/doc/percona-xtradb-cluster/LATEST/howtos/virt_sandbox.html

Change-Id: Ie1b3b9724dd33de1d90634166e585ecceb1f4c96

commit_message:
Implement a proper WSREP check for galera

The galera cluster rely on WSREP for cluster consistency. While the
default MySQL monitor will allow us to know when the database node is
minimally functional it does not provide the ability to query the node
state allowing loadbalancers, operators, and deployers to know a node
is healthy prior to being allowed to accept connections. This change
implements the checkcluster script as provided by the fine folks at
Percona. The implementation of this check follows the guild-lines noted
here [0]. With this in-place, we'll be able to convert our haproxy check
for the galera cluster nodes to use an HTTP check on port 9200 instead
of the default MySQL login which will provide for a more robust and
fault tolerant cluster.

[0] https://www.percona.com/doc/percona-xtradb-cluster/LATEST/howtos/virt_sandbox.html
Closes-Bug: #1665667

Change-Id: Ie1b3b9724dd33de1d90634166e585ecceb1f4c96
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Prevent apache from listening on default ports

This fixes an issue where the containers used for TLS proxy would
listen on the same port and thus fail to start with:

(98)Address already in use: AH00072: make_sock: could not bind to
address [::]:80
(98)Address already in use: AH00072: make_sock: could not bind to
address 0.0.0.0:80

This change applies the same logic that Kolla does for containers
images with apache in it:

https://github.com/openstack/kolla/blob/31259fa595392c25a5e21d03c13e8896648a7695/docker/heat/heat-base/Dockerfile.j2#L20-L21
https://github.com/openstack/kolla/blob/31259fa595392c25a5e21d03c13e8896648a7695/docker/heat/heat-base/extend_start.sh#L10-L21

Change-Id: Ic2fd3f65b06755ae0869af7b39bcdbcb8ec03774
Closes-Bug: #1734879
